DeregistrationReasonOtherText: no longer covered by the RMP, 40 CFR Part 68

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA?s RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR 
CARTEX CORPORATION/WOODBRIDGE GROUP

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Cartex Corporation, as part of the Woodbridge Group of companies, believes that the health and safety of its employees and the protection of the natural environment should be of the utmost concern in the operation of its business. Cartex is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.

Cartex Corporations policy:
-    Comply with all applicable laws, regulations, and standards.
-    Review and assess our operations for the purpose of making health, safety and environmental improvements.

A combination of prevention programs and emergency response planning programs are used to help ensure the safety of employees, the public, as well as protection of the environment. The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner, including the implementation of the Program 2 elements as outlined in the Risk Management Plan. To ensure that the RMP program is appropriately developed, implemented, and maintained, the Plant Manager has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to a staff member with the background, training, and experience necessary to manager the program. 

2.    Facility and Regulated Substances

The primary operation at Cartex is to manufacturer polyurethane foam for the automotive industry. The foam is made by high pressure mixing of chemicals immediately prior to pouring the mixture into a pre-shaped mold that is attached to carriers on a moving carrousel line. After the pouring takes place, the molds moved through a curing oven. Upon exiting the oven, the foam pads are manually removed from the molds, crushed, trimmed, and prepared for shipment to customers. 

Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) is the main reactant required to produce polyurethane foam. TDI is regulated under EPA?s RMP program rule. TDI is received at the

plant by either railcar of tanker truck. It is stored in two registered above ground storage tanks (AST?s) in a special enclosed and contained room. TDI is then transferred to the process utilizing a computer controlled system. 

Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel, and contractors. The maximum amount of TDI that can be stored in the facility is 275,000 pounds.

3.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Cartex complies with various OSHA regulations, EPA Clean Air Act, DOT transportation of Hazardous Goods, and NFPA Codes through specific prevention programs.

Key features of the prevention program for use of TDI at Cartex include:

?    Safety information
?    Hazard review
?    Operating procedures
?    Training
?    Equipment maintenance
?    Corporate audits
?    Accident/Incident investigation
?    Emergency response

An established Isocyanate control program outlines the hazards of handling TDI and the controls which are in place to reduce the hazards of Isocyanate exposure to employees, the community and the environment.

4.    Five year history

There have been no TDI releases that qualify for listing in the EPA?s required five year history report.

5.    Emergency Response Program

An established integrated contingency plan consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. An internal Emergency Response Team (ERT) is trained to the Hazardous Materials Technician Level and is capable of responding to any chemical release at this facility. The ERT members participate in drills simulating different TDI release scenarios. The Emergency Response Plan is also coordinated with the LEPC and fire department. Local hospitals have also been given information regarding medical treatment for exposure to TDI.

6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

All safety management systems are reviewed on a continuous basis and updated when necessary. Recomme
ndations from the Hazard Review shall be addressed including follow up reviews to ensure that effective corrective actions were taken.
